<a href="https://getdivvy.com/morningbrew/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=sponsored-email&utm_campaign=Mar-3&utm_term=my100&utm_content=email&AID=7011V000001IHWKQA4" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="Divvy" style="width:100%;max-width: 125px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="125" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby8xLzE1NzYwNzcxNjYtMTU2NDYwODk2OS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJjb21ldC1tb3JuaW5nYnJldyIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19"></a>
</th>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good Tuesday morning. </strong>They say there’s a German word for everything, so obviously there’s one for hoarding items during times of widespread panic. <em>Hamsterkauf</em> comes from the verb “hamstern,” which means to panic-buy...and yes, there’s a connection to hamsters, which store food in their cheeks. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Use it in a sentence: </strong></span><span>German grocery stores have been experiencing a wave of Hamsterkauf during the coronavirus scare. </span>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
C-SUITE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/02/csuite-icon-jack-welch-dies-84?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Management Icon Jack Welch Dies at 84
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jack Welch " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NS9qYWNrX3dlbGNoLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Brooks Kraft/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We weren't expecting to lead with two obituaries to start off the week, but famed GE boss Jack Welch has died, leaving behind a <a href="https://apnews.com/8040b13eb8d980e9ecb4198ff0e314a2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">complex legacy</a> in corporate America.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Working without boundaries </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before the cult of the Silicon Valley founder, there was the cult of Jack Welch. He joined GE in 1960 then worked his way up to the top job in 1981. Over the next 20 years, Welch <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/jack-welch-legendary-ceo-of-general-electric-dies-at-age-84-11583158270?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">turned GE</a> into a $410 billion conglomerate spanning tech, financial services, energy, healthcare, and media.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Welch unwound decades of bureaucracy and created a "boundaryless" organization that encouraged new ideas. In 1999, Fortune named him "Manager of the Century." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How’d he do it? </strong>Welch cut inefficiencies like a baker cuts bread, taking a "fix it, close it, or sell it" approach to departments and people. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In his first 10 years in charge, he </span><span><a href="https://www.ft.com/content/f304d8f8-07c0-11ea-9afa-d9e2401fa7ca?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">eliminated</a></span><span> 170,000 jobs, earning the nickname "Neutron Jack" after the neutron bomb, which leaves buildings standing but wipes out everyone in them. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Welch retired on Sept. 7, 2001. Four days later, his successor Jeffrey Immelt was left steering GE through a national crisis. Immelt was <em>also</em> left handling the fallout from Welch's more questionable decisions, like building out GE Capital (which nearly dragged the whole company down in 2008).</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Today, GE's worth <$100 billion, and a string of CEOs have sold off non-core divisions in an effort to slim down and refocus. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Welch later acknowledged his relentless pursuit of shareholder value was problematic, and argued a company's main constituencies should be employees, customers, and products. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Training the next generation </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At GE, Welch famously prioritized leadership development. Internal programs, including <a href="https://slate.com/business/2014/06/ges-crotonville-management-campus-where-future-company-leaders-are-trained.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">retreats</a> to GE's Crotonville campus, were a launching pad for hand-picked protégés and high-achievers to receive executive coaching. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>For Welch, GE had to be first or second—or nothing. The unforgiving management style he used to achieve that inspired a generation of execs who now head their own Fortune 500 companies.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/02/robinhood-goes-historic-day-stock-market?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Robinhood Stock Blocks Investors
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What's worse than going to a Super Bowl party while on Whole30? Trying to buy stocks on Robinhood while the Dow is having one of its best days in history. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The no-fee investing app <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/02/robinhood-says-its-experiencing-a-system-wide-outage-as-markets-rebound-in-heavy-volume-monday.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suffered a "systemwide outage</a>" yesterday, blocking many users from joining the market's mega-rally. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The diagnosis? </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Early reports speculate the app was hit by intense volume. Robinhood is popular among younger traders who may have been trying to "buy the dip" following last week's market rout. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But others </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/Alay_989/status/1234606593431437313?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suggested</a></span><span> that Robinhood was offline because its </span><span><em>code didn’t account for Leap Year</em></span><span>. Which would be crazy considering we wrote about that </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/oversights-computer-code-can-lead-leap-day-slipups?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">exact issue</a></span><span> on Saturday. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Either way, we do not envy Robinhood's social media team, which spent yesterday responding to <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=robinhood%20&src=typed_query&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">irate users</a> feeling market FOMO. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Robinhood successfully disrupted the brokerage industry with its no-fee model. But it didn't show up when it mattered yesterday. </p>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<img alt="Map showing air pollution over China " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MC9jaGluYV9haXJfcG9sbHV0aW9uX2xldmVscy5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>NASA</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Less air pollution. NASA and the European Space Agency said their pollution monitoring satellites found “<a href="https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/146362/airborne-nitrogen-dioxide-plummets-over-china?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">significant decreases</a>” in nitrogen dioxide over China. That's "at least partly related to the economic slowdown" from the coronavirus outbreak. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Nitrogen dioxide (NO</span><span><sub style="display: inline-block; line-height: 16px;">2</sub></span><span>) is a gas released by cars and power plants. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Researchers said this drop-off was without precedent. Pollution fell in Beijing around the 2008 Olympics, but that was localized and temporary. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The economic data backs it up: </strong>The official gauge of China’s manufacturing sector nosedived to its <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-29/china-feb-manufacturing-pmi-at-35-7-est-45-0?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lowest level</a> on record in February.</p>

</tr>
</table>
<img alt="looking at Big Tech through a microscope" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83Mi9iaWdfdGVjaF9taWNyb3Njb3BlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Verge released the results of its second <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/2/21144680/verge-tech-survey-2020-trust-privacy-security-facebook-amazon-google-apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Tech Trust Survey</a> yesterday. Our big takeaways:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bezos has a fan club. </strong>Amazon had the highest favorability rating out of all tech brands (91%). And 81% said they'd be disappointed if Amazon disappeared, second only to Google. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Twitter who? </strong>33% said they'd be disappointed if Twitter was wiped off the face of the planet. 43% trust Twitter with their information...only slightly more than last-place Facebook.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Speaking of Facebook, </strong>72% said the company has too much power. And when asked their top reasons for not using Facebook, "not interested in the content" was No. 2.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">More people need to read the Brew. </strong>Just 38% of respondents knew that Facebook owns Instagram, 29% knew it owns WhatsApp, and 12% knew Amazon owns Twitch. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Maybe the techlash is overrated. Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple<span>—</span>the four largest U.S. tech companies by market cap<span>—were rated as having the most positive impact on society. </span></p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/02/quick-debrief-central-bank-meetings?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Nothing Cuts Deeper Than Monetary Policy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Welcome to Day 2 of our weeklong series explaining the main events on the economic calendar. Today we’re traveling Down Under to learn more about central bank meetings.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who’s meeting: </strong>Earlier today, Australia’s central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, gathered for a lively debate on monetary policy over vegemite finger sammies. Central banks are the orchestra conductors for economies around the world. In the U.S., the Fed's goal is to stabilize inflation and maximize employment. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Australia's got it down pat. The country hasn’t had a recession in 29 years.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How central banks do it: </strong>During their meetings, central banks make decisions on the <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/economics/08/interest-rate-affecting-consumers.asp?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">target interest rate</a>—the guideline banks use when setting bank-to-bank lending rates. When central banks reduce the target rate, it becomes less expensive to borrow money. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Banks feel it first, but eventually interest rate cuts trickle down to regular folks through lower mortgage rates and lower interest rates on savings accounts.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A central bank raising rates does just the opposite: It slows down an economy that’s too hot to handle.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Current rates are historically low across developed economies. Fresh cuts to deal with the economic impact of the coronavirus could leave central banks with less ammo if downturns get worse. </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What do Madonna, Mark Zuckerberg, and Mike Bloomberg have in common? They all get name-dropped by social media personality The Fat Jewish the second you ask him to talk about the influencer economy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week on Morning Brew’s </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>Business Casual</em></strong><strong style="color:#000"> podcast</strong>, we did just that. The Fat Jewish (real name: Josh Ostrovsky) takes us on a roller coaster ride of content, from selling his Babe wine brand to AB InBev to Mike Bloomberg’s now-famous meme campaign for the White House.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And on Super Tuesday, Bloomberg’s social strategy matters. Josh breaks an NDA with Bloomberg’s camp to explain exactly how those fake DMs will play out. Want to know how it ends? Listen to the pod.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Also on tap this episode...</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>When the influencer marketing bubble will pop</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>How to reverse engineer your audience into an R&D flywheel</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Tangible examples of “cutting through the noise” that don’t sound like they came from a startup-for-dummies book.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Do not miss this one. </strong>Listen here: <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/fatjewish_apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/fatjewish_spotify?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/fatjewish_all?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a></p>

Amy Klobuchar \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/amy-klobuchar-drops-out-presidential-race-will-endorse-biden-n1147191?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edropped out\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003e yesterday as the more moderate Dems try to form a firewall against Sen. The index \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/us-manufacturers-slow-to-a-crawl-as-coronavirus-bottlenecks-emerge-ism-shows-2020-03-02?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edipped\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to 50.1 in February due to coronavirus-related bottlenecks. width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NS9qYWNrX3dlbGNoLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eBrooks Kraft/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe weren't expecting to lead with two obituaries to start off the week, but famed GE boss Jack Welch has died, leaving behind a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/8040b13eb8d980e9ecb4198ff0e314a2?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecomplex legacy\u003c/a\u003e in corporate America.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWorking without boundaries \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBefore the cult of the Silicon Valley founder, there was the cult of Jack Welch. He joined GE in 1960 then worked his way up to the top job in 1981. Over the next 20 years, Welch \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/jack-welch-legendary-ceo-of-general-electric-dies-at-age-84-11583158270?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eturned GE\u003c/a\u003e into a $410 billion conglomerate spanning tech, financial services, energy, healthcare, and media.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWelch unwound decades of bureaucracy and created a \"boundaryless\" organization that encouraged new ideas. In 1999, Fortune named him \"Manager of the Century.\" \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow’d he do it? \u003c/strong\u003eWelch cut inefficiencies like a baker cuts bread, taking a \"fix it, close it, or sell it\" approach to departments and people. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn his first 10 years in charge, he \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/f304d8f8-07c0-11ea-9afa-d9e2401fa7ca?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeliminated\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e 170,000 jobs, earning the nickname \"Neutron Jack\" after the neutron bomb, which leaves buildings standing but wipes out everyone in them. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWelch retired on Sept. 7, 2001. Four days later, his successor Jeffrey Immelt was left steering GE through a national crisis. Immelt was \u003cem\u003ealso\u003c/em\u003e left handling the fallout from Welch's more questionable decisions, like building out GE Capital (which nearly dragged the whole company down in 2008).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eToday, GE's worth \u003c$100 billion, and a string of CEOs have sold off non-core divisions in an effort to slim down and refocus. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Welch later acknowledged his relentless pursuit of shareholder value was problematic, and argued a company's main constituencies should be employees, customers, and products. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTraining the next generation \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt GE, Welch famously prioritized leadership development. Internal programs, including \u003ca href=\"https://slate.com/business/2014/06/ges-crotonville-management-campus-where-future-company-leaders-are-trained.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eretreats\u003c/a\u003e to GE's Crotonville campus, were a launching pad for hand-picked protégés and high-achievers to receive executive coaching. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eFor Welch, GE had to be first or second—or nothing. The unforgiving management style he used to achieve that inspired a generation of execs who now head their own Fortune 500 companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhat's worse than going to a Super Bowl party while on Whole30? Trying to buy stocks on Robinhood while the Dow is having one of its best days in history. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe no-fee investing app \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/02/robinhood-says-its-experiencing-a-system-wide-outage-as-markets-rebound-in-heavy-volume-monday.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuffered a \"systemwide outage\u003c/a\u003e\" yesterday, blocking many users from joining the market's mega-rally. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe diagnosis? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEarly reports speculate the app was hit by intense volume. Robinhood is popular among younger traders who may have been trying to \"buy the dip\" following last week's market rout. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBut others \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Alay_989/status/1234606593431437313?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuggested\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that Robinhood was offline because its \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003ecode didn’t account for Leap Year\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Which would be crazy considering we wrote about that \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/oversights-computer-code-can-lead-leap-day-slipups?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexact issue\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on Saturday. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEither way, we do not envy Robinhood's social media team, which spent yesterday responding to \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/search?q=robinhood%20\u0026src=typed_query\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eirate users\u003c/a\u003e feeling market FOMO. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eRobinhood successfully disrupted the brokerage industry with its no-fee model. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLess air pollution. NASA and the European Space Agency said their pollution monitoring satellites found “\u003ca href=\"https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/146362/airborne-nitrogen-dioxide-plummets-over-china?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esignificant decreases\u003c/a\u003e” in nitrogen dioxide over China. That's \"at least partly related to the economic slowdown\" from the coronavirus outbreak. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eNitrogen dioxide (NO\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003csub style=\"display: inline-block; line-height: 16px;\"\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e) is a gas released by cars and power plants. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eResearchers said this drop-off was without precedent. Pollution fell in Beijing around the 2008 Olympics, but that was localized and temporary. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe economic data backs it up: \u003c/strong\u003eThe official gauge of China’s manufacturing sector nosedived to its \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-29/china-feb-manufacturing-pmi-at-35-7-est-45-0?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elowest level\u003c/a\u003e on record in February.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Verge released the results of its second \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/2/21144680/verge-tech-survey-2020-trust-privacy-security-facebook-amazon-google-apple?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eTech Trust Survey\u003c/a\u003e yesterday. Our big takeaways:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBezos has a fan club. \u003c/strong\u003eAmazon had the highest favorability rating out of all tech brands (91%). And 81% said they'd be disappointed if Amazon disappeared, second only to Google. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTwitter who? \u003c/strong\u003e33% said they'd be disappointed if Twitter was wiped off the face of the planet. 43% trust Twitter with their information...only slightly more than last-place Facebook.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSpeaking of Facebook, \u003c/strong\u003e72% said the company has too much power. And when asked their top reasons for not using Facebook, \"not interested in the content\" was No. 2.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMore people need to read the Brew. \u003c/strong\u003eJust 38% of respondents knew that Facebook owns Instagram, 29% knew it owns WhatsApp, and 12% knew Amazon owns Twitch. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eMaybe the techlash is overrated. Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple\u003cspan\u003e—\u003c/span\u003ethe four largest U.S. tech companies by market cap\u003cspan\u003e—were rated as having the most positive impact on style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nNothing Cuts Deeper Than Monetary Policy\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWelcome to Day 2 of our weeklong series explaining the main events on the economic calendar. Today we’re traveling Down Under to learn more about central bank meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWho’s meeting: \u003c/strong\u003eEarlier today, Australia’s central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, gathered for a lively debate on monetary policy over vegemite finger sammies. Central banks are the orchestra conductors for economies around the world. In the U.S., the Fed's goal is to stabilize inflation and maximize employment. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAustralia's got it down pat. The country hasn’t had a recession in 29 years.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow central banks do it: \u003c/strong\u003eDuring their meetings, central banks make decisions on the \u003ca href=\"https://www.investopedia.com/articles/economics/08/interest-rate-affecting-consumers.asp?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etarget interest rate\u003c/a\u003e—the guideline banks use when setting bank-to-bank lending rates. When central banks reduce the target rate, it becomes less expensive to borrow money. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBanks feel it first, but eventually interest rate cuts trickle down to regular folks through lower mortgage rates and lower interest rates on savings accounts.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eA central bank raising rates does just the opposite: It slows down an economy that’s too hot to handle.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Current rates are historically low across developed economies. Fresh cuts to deal with the economic impact of the coronavirus could leave central banks with less ammo if downturns get worse. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F03%2F02%2Fquick-debrief-central-bank-meetings\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
